entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. In the context of Bitcoin/CivKit, front-running could occur when a bulletin board operator discovers a batch of market offers and takes advantage of the opportunity before publishing the offer on its board.The conversation introduces three main characters: Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator. Mary publishes a limit order to buy a derivative, and Bob has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob decides not to execute, he relays the order to Terry (and other subscribers to Bob's market), who then has the option to execute the trade. If Terry chooses not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.There is a debate about whether this model is a concern or not. Some argue that if Bob can collect outsized profits from his position as the bulletin board operator, Terry will eventually move to other markets. It is suggested that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete on quoting prices with Bob. The idea is that Bob and Terry can be compared on metrics like execution quality, which will draw more market activity since they are providing better prices.The concept of front-running resistance is discussed, and two security paradigms are proposed. One paradigm involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple independent boards and monitoring latency anomalies. Latency anomalies could indicate misbehaving boards, and makers can disqualify them from future announcements. The second paradigm suggests running the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT or similar techniques. Offers become consensus items announced to all federation members, and payment credentials are required for publication.The conversation also touches on the importance of user experience and finding what products people are interested in trading. It is argued that front-running is a good problem to have since it indicates active participants and liquidity. The discussion concludes by mentioning the potential use of reputation frameworks, web-of-stakes, and privacy-preserving credentials to incentivize service operators and ensure efficient market operations.A group consisting of Nicholas Gregory, Ray Youssef, and Antoine Riard is working on a peer-to-peer market system that aims to facilitate censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design of the system combines the Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing infrastructure to ensure a high level of confidentiality for market participants.In the proposed system, the market boards are Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway, operating autonomously and in competition with each other. Trades are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, with moderations and know your peer oracles used for adjudication.One important aspect highlighted in the feedback received on the paper publication is the need to underscore front-running resistance as a fundamental property desired for a peer-to-peer marketplace. The level of front-running resistance aimed by market participants will depend on the types of trades considered. Different classes of goods may have varying levels of item liquidity and exposure to front-running risks, requiring accurate risk modeling.To mitigate front-running in peer-to-peer marketplaces, two security paradigms are proposed. The first involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring latency for anomalies. Latency anomalies can be detected by watchtower-like infrastructure, allowing makers to disqualify misbehaving boards. The second paradigm suggests running the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT consensus, where incoming board offers become consensus items announced to all federation members' onion gateways.The whitepaper also discusses the scoring of trades, counterparties, and service operators through the introduction of a Web-of-Stakes. This reputation paradigm assigns an economic weight to each market entity based on the Bitcoin UTXO set as a trustless source of truth. It can be combined with decentralized identifier techniques to create a comprehensive scoring system.To incentivize service operators, a consistent framework is proposed using privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments, following the principles of IETF's Privacy Pass. This framework aims to incentivize efficiency, similar to routing hops on Lightning and miners on the base layer.The researchers plan to release code and modules gradually, building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. They aim to collaborate with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients. The goal is to adhere to the best Bitcoin open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core, with a long-term perspective in mind.Overall, the proposed peer-to-peer market system combines various architectural elements to enable censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading while addressing front-running risks and providing incentives for service operators. Feedback on the system is welcomed.
